"the American Medical Association and World Health Organization, have concluded from the research of independent groups worldwide that genetically modified foods are safe for consumers [4]. This means the the wheels will fall off more easily when you destroy the circle of life there.  The ocean produces 2/3 -3/4 of the oxygen needed to sustain all life.

Imagine what this would do for the Sushi and Sashimi market if they could pull the same trick with Tuna. Most of the fish used there are expensive mainly because of size, and scarcity of catch, but also because the mortality rate of the eggs is incredibly low compared to farmed fish. The other positive is the mercury levels of the fish are substantially lower or virtually non-existent. The downside? Farm fish tend to lack the same firmness of wild-catch - either because of salinity issues, stress levels, or something as simple as lack of exercise having to swim in naturally changing currents. Either way - we farm Tilapia, Carp, Salmon, Catfish and a multitude of other species of fish ... it's not really that big of a deal. I'd even wager some grow faster simply because the lab controls the feedings, keeps it consistent and plentiful, and the tanks are far less stressful with no predators or temperature swings to stunt growth.

There is a program way to buy into the stock market that removes your emotions from you buying.  Naturally when buying is the emotion in play you buy on stock price increases.  Naturally when selling is the emotion in play you don't buy when prices decrease.  This is called dollar cost averaging.  A Maine lobsterman didn't need super expensive Harvard types to implement this in his job.  He created an enclosed tidal pool and took a portion of his catch when prices are low and stored them.  Then when prices rebound he supplemented his catch from the tidal pool.  It does not take college and degrees to make smart decisions.
